Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: I glanced at my watch, feeling the weight of the day pressing down on me. My shift as a housekeeping cleaner was supposed to start in an hour, and I still had to deep clean every room in the house before my supervisor’s inspection. But here I was, in the middle of the supermarket, with my son darting between aisles, giggling as he knocked over a display of cereal boxes. Other shoppers stared, some with disapproval, others with sympathy. I knew I should stop him, kneel down, and teach him about respect and discipline—about how we treat public spaces and other people’s property. That’s what a good mother would do. But my mind kept racing back to the list of rooms waiting for me, the thought of missing a single spot and facing my supervisor’s disappointment. I felt torn, my heart pounding with anxiety. Should I take the time to correct my son, risking being late and not meeting the cleaning standards at work? Or should I rush him along, ignoring the lesson he needed, just to make sure I didn’t fail at my job? The expectations from both sides pulled at me, and I stood frozen, caught between the two worlds I was supposed to manage.
